description: From Middle English anent, anempt (“insofar as, inasmuch as, in comparison with, with respect to, as regards, concerning, in the opinion or judgment of; next to, close to, up to, near, adjoining, across from, over against, facing”), from Old English onemn (“by; near”), from on +‎ enm; synchronically analyzable as on- +‎ even. Compare Dutch neven, German neben.

entries.meaning: (now rare) Concerning, with regard to, about, in respect to, as to, insofar as, inasmuch as, apropos.
examples: Synonyms: apropos, as for; see also Thesaurus:about

entries.meaning: (obsolete) In the opinion or judgment of.
(obsolete) Against, in front of, fronting; before; opposite; over against, on the other side.
examples: […]  if Painter did ever abide in the old bark mill said to be anent his brother's freehold.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) In a line with; side by side with; on a level with.
